head.title: Give Global Warming the Acid Rain Test

hedline.hl1: Give Global Warming the Acid Rain Test

block.p: In ''Global Lukewarming'' (editorial, Nov. 5), you address two major environmental issues - clean air and global warming - but you treat them as unrelated. The Clean Air Act amendments that are pending in Congress offer an unusual opportunity to attack the two intertwined problems of acid rain and global warming simultaneously.

Separation of these problems, whether by environmentalists, legislators or editors, risks reducing public understanding and missing a rare opportunity to make real progress now, not 10 years from now.

Energy conservation and renewable energy sources are our best weapons against atmospheric calamity because they simultaneously reduce both sulfur dioxide (the key ingredient of acid rain) and carbon dioxide (the primary culprit in global warming).

Yet, the President's clean air bill, as it has been proposed, focuses so narrowly on sulfur dioxide reduction that it perversely encourages utilities to shun conservation and renewables in favor of switching to low-sulfur fuels or stack scrubbing.
Unfortunately, stack scrubbing and low-sulfur fuels make our global warming problems worse by increasing carbon dioxide emissions.

I intend to introduce an amendment to the clean air legislation that will reward electric utilities that implement conservation and renewables programs early and often. This will not only mitigate acid rain and global warming, but it will reduce consumer energy bills and national energy consumption as well.

It would be the height of folly for Congress to pass an acid rain bill in 1990 that increases carbon dioxide emissions at a time when an international conference in the Netherlands is working on a worldwide agreement to counter the effects of global warming. EDWARD J. MARKEY
Member of Congress, 7th Dist., Mass. Washington, Nov. 7, 1989
